sent: 7816 Hanoi was discovered on 18 December 1987, by Japanese astronomer Masahiro Koishikawa at the Ayashi Station (391) of the Sendai Astronomical Observatory, Japan, and later named after the Vietnamese capital of Hanoi.
(386723) 2009 YE, provisional designation 2009 YE, is a trans-Neptunian object (TNO) discovered by David Rabinowitz on December 17, 2009 at the La Silla Observatory in Chile.
24260 Kriváň was discovered by Slovak astronomer Peter Kušnirák at the Czech Ondřejov Observatory on 13 December 1999, and named after the Kriváň mountain peak in Slovakia.
The asteroid was named in memory of Alexander Nedzel, a manager at MIT Lincoln Laboratory.
( 11474 ) 1982 SM2 was discovered on 18 September 1982, by Belgian astronomer Henri Debehogne at ESO' La Silla Observatory in northern Chile.

Aletheia (minor planet designation: 259 Aletheia) is a very large main-belt asteroid that was discovered by German-American astronomer Christian Peters on June 28, 1886, at Litchfield Observatory, Clinton, New York.
4959 Niinoama was discovered by Japanese astronomers Akira Natori and Takeshi Urata at JCPM Yakiimo Station on 15 August 1991.
102 Miriam was discovered by C. H. F. Peters on August 22, 1868, from the Litchfield Observatory.
31179 Gongju was discovered on 21 December 1997, by Japanese amateur astronomer Naoto Sato at his Chichibu Observatory near Tokyo, central Japan.
1270 Datura was discovered on 17 December 1930, by Belgian-American George Van Biesbroeck at the Yerkes Observatory in Williams Bay, Wisconsin, United States.
Hestia was discovered by N. R. Pogson on August 16, 1857, at the Radcliffe Observatory, Oxford.
1951 Lick was discovered on 26 July 1949, by American astronomer Carl Wirtanen at Lick Observatory on the summit of Mount Hamilton, California, and named for American philanthropist James Lick.
21088 Chelyabinsk was discovered on 30 January 1992, by Belgian astronomer Eric Elst at ESO's La Silla Observatory in northern Chile.
2674 Pandarus was discovered on 27 January 1982, by astronomers at Harvard's Oak Ridge Observatory near Harvard, Massachusetts, in the United States.
NGC 2403 (also known as Caldwell 7) is an intermediate spiral galaxy in the constellation Camelopardalis.

Messier 99 or M99, also known as NGC 4254, is a grand design spiral galaxy in the northern constellation Coma Berenices approximately 15 megaparsecs (49 megalight-years) in distance from the Milky Way.
NGC 327 is a spiral galaxy in the constellation Cetus.
IC 335 is a lenticular galaxy about 60 million light years (18 million parsecs) away, in the constellation Fornax.
NGC 298 is a spiral galaxy in the constellation Cetus.
Messier 91 (also known as NGC 4548 or M91) is a barred spiral galaxy located in the Coma Berenices constellation and is part of the Virgo Cluster of galaxies.
NGC 3344 is a relatively isolated barred spiral galaxy located 22.5 million light years away in the constellation Leo Minor.
NGC 166 (also known as PGC 2143) is a spiral galaxy located around 2.6 million light-years away in the constellation Cetus, with an apparent magnitude of 15.18.
NGC 413 is a spiral galaxy of type SB(r)c located in the constellation Cetus.
NGC 168 is a lenticular galaxy located in the constellation Cetus.
Located in Ursa Major, a constellation in the northern sky, IC 2574 is an outlying member of the M81 Group.
NGC 191 is a spiral galaxy located in the constellation Cetus.
NGC 5201 is a spiral galaxy located in the constellation Ursa Major.
NGC 320 is a spiral galaxy in the constellation Cetus.
NGC 806 is a spiral galaxy approximately 166 million light-years away from Earth in the constellation Cetus.
NGC 5640 is a spiral galaxy approximately 660 million light-years away from Earth in the constellation of Camelopardalis.

Messier 100 (also known as NGC 4321) is a grand design intermediate spiral galaxy located within the southern part of constellation Coma Berenices.
NGC 4090 is a spiral galaxy located 340 million light-years away in the constellation Coma Berenices.
NGC 4656/57 is a highly warped barred spiral galaxy located in the constellation Canes Venatici and is sometimes informally called the Hockey Stick Galaxies or the Crowbar Galaxy.
NGC 4907 is a barred spiral galaxy located about 270 million light-years away in the constellation of Coma Berenices.
NGC 2857 (also known as Arp 1 and PGC 26666) is a spiral galaxy in the constellation Ursa Major.
NGC 4314 is a barred spiral galaxy approximately 40 million light-years away in the constellation Coma Berenices.
ISOHDFS 27 is a spiral galaxy in the constellation Tucana, and was discovered in the Hubble Deep Field South survey.
NGC 681 (also known as the Little Sombrero Galaxy) is an intermediate spiral galaxy in the constellation of Cetus, located approximately 66.5 million light-years from Earth.
NGC 4515 is a lenticular galaxy located about 57 million light-years away in the constellation Coma Berenices.
NGC 345 is a spiral galaxy located in the constellation Cetus.
NGC 493, also occasionally referred to as PGC 4979 or GC 281, is a barred spiral galaxy in the constellation Cetus.
NGC 4945 (also known as Caldwell 83) is a barred spiral galaxy in the constellation Centaurus, visible near the  star Xi Centauri.

Messier 109 (also known as NGC 3992) is a barred spiral galaxy exhibiting a weak inner ring structure around the central bar approximately 83.5 Â± 24 million light-years away in the constellation Ursa Major.
Messier 88 (also known as M88 or NGC 4501) is a spiral galaxy about 50 to 60 million light-years away in the constellation Coma Berenices.
Malin 1 is located 1.19Â billion light-years (366Â Mpc) away in the constellation Coma Berenices, near the North Galactic Pole.
NGC 142 is a spiral galaxy in the constellation of Cetus.
NGC 5714 is a spiral galaxy located 130 million light-years away in the constellation of Boötes (the Herdsman).
NGC 4516 is a barred spiral galaxy located about 55 million light-years away in the constellation Coma Berenices.
NGC 2841 is an inclined, unbarred, spiral galaxy in the constellation Ursa Major that exhibits a prominent inner ring structure.
NGC 356 is a spiral galaxy in the constellation Cetus.
NGC 4725 is an intermediate barred spiral galaxy with a prominent ring structure about 40 million light-years away in the constellation Coma Berenices.
NGC 3184 is a spiral galaxy approximately 40 million light-years away in the constellation Ursa Major.
NGC 1015 is a barred spiral galaxy, at a distance of 118 million light years in the constellation of Cetus (The Whale).
NGC 347 is a spiral galaxy in the constellation Cetus.
NGC 344 is a barred spiral galaxy in the constellation Cetus.
NGC 167 is a spiral galaxy located approximately 172 million light-years from the Solar System in the constellation Cetus.
NGC 367 is a spiral galaxy in the constellation of Cetus.
NGC 4565 (also known as the Needle Galaxy or Caldwell 38) is an edge-on spiral galaxy about 30 to 50 million light-years away in the constellation Coma Berenices.
NGC 331 is a barred spiral galaxy in the constellation Cetus.
NGC 7003 is a spiral galaxy around 220 million light-years  from Earth in the constellation Delphinus.
NGC 7259 is a spiral galaxy approximately 66 million light-years away from Earth in the constellation of Piscis Austrinus.
NGC 276 is a barred spiral galaxy located approximately 626 million light-years from the Solar System in the constellation Cetus.
NGC 303 is a lenticular galaxy in the constellation Cetus.

The Soyuz spacecraft launched from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan on Tuesday, 7 June 2011 at 20:12 UTC (8 June 2011, 02:12  local time).
After three orbits, the spacecraft re-entered the Earth's atmosphere, splashed down in the North Atlantic Ocean, and was safely taken aboard USS Noa.
